name: Metrics
emptyReason: After deep-reading all 135 Sunday Thoughts articles, none were found with genuine relevance to performance metrics and KPIs.
description: "Measure what is measurable and make measurable what is not so." — Galileo. This session focuses on eliminating subjectivity through measurement, and building daily habits that compound into huge results.
discussionPoints: What do you measure (for self and/or the team)?
What does your manager measure?
What are predictable measures? Seasonal measures?
What is measured in your appraisal?
7 Tiny Daily Habits That Lead to Huge Results (Nicolas Cole):
1. Wake up when you say you're going to wake up — keep the first promise of the day
2. Write down 10 ideas per day — flex your creative muscle
3. Eat a healthy breakfast, lunch, and dinner — use meals as anchors for reading, networking, and family
4. Read for 30 minutes every day — that's 24 books a year
5. Get back in your body — 30-60 minutes of physical activity to maintain a clear head
6. Meditate for 15 minutes — make time to get in touch with your thoughts
7. Reflect before bed — jot down what went well and what to do differently tomorrow

prompts: What metrics am I already tracking that I should continue?

prompts: What new metrics should I begin tracking?

name: Being Charismatic
description: Charisma isn't about being loud — it's about being authentic. This session explores the spectrum of interaction styles, from arrogance to acceptance, and how trust is the most important aspect of leadership.
discussionPoints: 8 small signs people use to judge your personality — how you treat waiters, your handshake, your punctuality all send signals
Being Authentic — The 5 As of Interaction:
1. Arrogance (Unacceptable)
2. Assertion
3. Authentic (Ideal Approach)
4. Accommodating
5. Accepting (Unacceptable)
Being Diplomatic — navigating with finesse
Finesse: Grooming, Comfort, and Crispness (being succinct)
Independence vs. Dependence — Knowing what I can do, what I cannot, and what I don't know
Delegation and Accountability
The most important aspect: Trust — built through experience, instincts, team, and relationships
